awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project:  Developing a Minor in Applied Mathematics at Savannah State University
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Savannah State University (SSU) seeks to develop a new applied math minor and make curricular improvements to upper level math courses that will strengthen the applied math focus. This project is aimed at improving the quality of math teaching and learning in upper level courses by offering the minor through an applied math, active learning focus. By engaging and inspiring students, the minor will increase enrollment in upper level math courses, and provide SSU STEM majors with the mathematical problem-solving skills demanded in the increasingly data-driven 21st century job market. The project is expected to strengthen the mathematical knowledge and capabilities and increase retention, graduation, and entry into competitive STEM jobs by minority applied math minors and other SSU graduates.

The overarching project goal is to establish a sustainable minor program in Applied Mathematics, and thereby increase undergraduate STEM enrollment, retention, graduation and entry into STEM jobs and graduate programs. The specific goals are to 1) increase interest and enrollment in math fields, 2) strengthen math teaching and learning and develop students' mathematical knowledge and problem solving capabilities, 3) strengthen connections to STEM careers, and 4) strengthen pipelines from K-12 to college math programs. The project will generate new knowledge and evidence on how an applied math minor program which includes interdisciplinary problems and an active learning approach will strengthen the mathematical problem solving skills and competencies of underrepresented minority students and their qualifications for competitive STEM jobs and graduate programs.

por.por_cntn:
In 2017, the National Science Foundation  awarded a grant of $399,972 to Savannah State University for support of the project entitled "Targeted Infusion Project:  Developing a Minor in Applied Mathematics at Savannah State University".    

The project has accomplished the following  major goals set by the proposal:

Goal 1: Increase interest, enrollment, and retention in STEM fields, through outreach and recruitment and delivery of the new Applied Mathematics minor. 

 The project enables the team  to develop a sustainable Applied Math minor at Savannah State university. Since Fall 2017 a total of 24 students have declared Applied Math as a minor, 14 of these students have already graduated with the minor

Goal 2: Strengthen and enhance math teaching and learning and develop students' mathematical knowledge, problem solving and critical thinking capabilities required in their discipline in order to solve problems in the real world and to strengthen their qualifications for STEM jobs, through interdisciplinary curriculum enhancements, new active learning strategies, and a seminar series. 

The  curriculum was designed by enhancing  courses that compose the new minor with applied math, real world applications and problems. The project team/ and other faculties from the math and other departments were involved in this activity.  Several professional development workshops and seminars for faculty and students  were organized, that helped faculties to gain experience in  a more engaging  teaching-learning activity.

 Goal 3:  Strengthen connections to the SSU academic/research family and to STEM careers, by providing support to students and faculty to enhance existing and develop new research projects and internships. 

Nineteen students conducted research projects in applied math topics. The students were awarded a scholarship and paired up with a  math faculty mentor  and/or  faculty from thier major field. Students have presented their work at ERN national conference, Savannah State research day, and Mathematics research week.

Goal 4: Strengthen pipelines between K-12 and SSU through recruitment and professional development for high school math teachers.

Since Fall 2017,  Professional workshops for math teachers were conducted every semester. The relationship between the Savannah area math teachers and Savannah state University grows and leads to the establishment of   the  "Savannah Math Teachers Circle". This accomplishment helps to build a foundation for sustaining this partnership with local teachers beyond the grant period and has the potential to impact future generations of students through the K-12 math educators.

In Summary:  The project helped SSU to establish  a minor in Applied Math by equipping the math courses with more real-world  applications that will  strengthen students' qualifications for STEM jobs.  Faculties had an opportunity to  gain experience on active learning strategies through workshops and seminars. The project enabled   STEM and non-STEM faculty to engage  in innovative, interdisciplinary, sustained collaborations to develop applied math applications. The project was also instrumental to strengthen pipelines between K-12 and SSU through outreach and through professional development for high school math teachers.
